thread.title: Anglo American swings back to profit and rows back on disposal plan
thread.title_full: Anglo American swings back to profit and rows back on disposal plan

author: Jon Yeomans
title: Anglo American swings back to profit and rows back on disposal plan
text:
Anglo American swings back to profit and rows back on disposal plan Anglo American returned to profit on the back of rising commodity prices Credit: VisMedia via Bloomberg News Jon Yeomans 21 February 2017 • 7:45am 
M ining giant Anglo American has turned its first annual profit in five years, while rowing back on a sweeping plan to sell off assets it hatched during the depths of the commodities downturn. 
The FTSE 100 group, which celebrates its 100th anniversary this year, swung to a pre-tax profit of $1.59bn (£1.28bn) in the year to December 31, from a loss of $5.6bn a year earlier. 
Underlying earnings before interest, tax and other charges jumped 25pc to $6bn, as an improvement in metal prices saw it rake in cash from iron ore and coal - two commodities it had vowed to exit in order to focus on diamonds, copper and platinum . 
Group revenue edged up 1pc to $23.1bn. A pit head at an Anglo American open pit mine in South Africa Credit: REUTERS/Siphiwe Sibeko 
M ark Cutifani, chief executive, pointed to the company's success in paring down its debt pile from $12.9bn to $8.4bn, easing the pressure on Anglo's balance sheet, and well below its target of $10bn net debt by the end of the year. 
As a result, Anglo will call a halt to the asset sale programme that had been intended to shrink it in size by almost two-thirds. 
"We will continue to upgrade our portfolio as a matter of course, although asset disposals for the purposes of deleveraging are no longer required," Mr Cutifani said. "We therefore retain [coal mines] Moranbah, Grosvenor and our nickel assets, ensuring that they continue to be optimised operationally to contribute cash and returns, while being allocated capital to both protect and enhance value." Mark Cutifani, chief executive officer Credit: Halden Krog/Bloomberg 
U nlike its peers in the mining sector , which have announced a return to shareholder payouts after stopping them during the downturn, Anglo ruled out a dividend this year. Dividends will now resume for the 2017 financial year. 
Anglo will continue to look at ways of divesting its coal assets in South Africa - its historic home, which has been beset by upheaval in the mining industry - but Mr Cutifani warned that even here, the miner may retreat on its plans. "The retention of these assets remains a viable position given our recent operational and other improvements," he said. 
Mr Cutifani has said repeatedly that Anglo's future lies with the commodities in which it has a world-class presence - such as diamonds, through its De Beers subsidiary; platinum, used in catalytic converters; and copper, which is used in electronics and housebuilding. 
But the unexpected recovery in the price of coal and iron, used in steelmaking, put the lie to this plan; Anglo's underlying earnings from these two commodities last year exceeded what it made from diamonds, platinum and copper put together.
